targets.Name: Babybear
targets.bannerText: This carseat should face the rear.
postText: Good find! Some car seats are designed to face the back of the car.
Now Babybear is safe because the car seat is being used correctly.
targets.hint: I'm soft but shed all over
Text: FURRY PET (Ex: Dogs, Cats, Hamsters, Guinea Pigs, and Rabbits) are common pet allergens that can trigger asthma symptoms in some people.Pet hair and dander, especially cat hair, can fly in the air and land on surfaces throughout the house...

targets.Name: Flowerbear
targets.bannerText: Both of Flowerbear's knees have to be over the seat to be safe.
postText: “Flower Bear” is not sitting with their knees bent over the edge of the seat.  This is not a safe way to ride in the car.

Before riding in the seatbelt, kids should be able to pass this 5 step test:
  1. Knees bend comfortably at the edge
  2. Bottom is all the way back in the seat
  3. Lap belt lies low on the hips, at the top of the thighs
  4. Shoulder belt crosses the shoulder
  5. They can ride like this the whole time

targets.Name: Bubblebear
targets.bannerText: Bubbles can distract the driver who needs to concentrate.
postText: Bubble Bear is having fun with his bubbles, but they can distract the driver.

When we’re in the car, it’s important for us to be good passengers and not distract the driver.  Bubble Bear will wait to use his bubbles until he’s outside of the car.  Can you think of other ways we can make sure we don’t distract the driver?
